newsitem.title: BOSNIA: Bosnia aid conference set for July 23-24.
newsitem.headline: Bosnia aid conference set for July 23-24.

text.p: The World Bank said on Tuesday an international conference to raise funds for Bosnia's peacetime reconstruction will be held on July 23-24 after a six-month delay caused by political bickering.
"The donors' conference has been agreed for July 23 and 24 in Brussels," Saumya Mitra, from the World Bank's office in Sarajevo, told Reuters.
"Invitations in the name of the World Bank and the European Commission will be going out today to Bosnian authorities and the donors," Mitra said.
The conference was originally scheduled for January but had to be postponed several times because of disputes between leaders from the country's Serb and Moslem-Croat territories.
Western officials said major powers decided to drop one of the conditions for the aid conference to avoid further delays.
Donor countries had previously demanded that Bosnia clinch a stand-by agreement with the International Monetary Fund (IMF) as a precondition for holding the conference.
But rival Serb and Moslem-Croat federation representatives could not agree on the design of an interim currency, which has held up the $100 million IMF deal.

The design of the currency is a politically sensitive issue in Bosnia, which was devastated by a 3-1/2 year war. Serb leaders have insisted on the use of nationalist symbols in the design which Bosnian Moslem officials find offensive.

The adoption last month of a package of economic legislation, including laws on a central bank, state budget, debt service and customs regulations, helped clear the way for the conference, Mitra said.
The World Bank hoped to win pledges from organisations and more than 30 donor governments for $1.4 billion in aid in 1997, he said.
The conference was expected to focus on raising funds for the restoration of the country's power and water networks and for the construction of housing for refugees.
Some foreign experts, who asked not to be named, said it was unclear whether the conference would manage to reach the 1.4 billion target.
"Whether the donors will really come up with that is not very unlikely. The mood among the donors is not the best," said one Western official, who asked not to be named.

Donor governments, facing their own economic troubles at home, might be reluctant to offer significant aid as long as Bosnia's inter-ethnic government remained virtually paralysed by political quarrels.
